slides.title: Welcome to Organic Chemistry
slides.content:
# Introduction to Organic Chemistry ðŸ§¬

Welcome to **Organic Chemistry** - the study of carbon-containing compounds!

## What you'll learn:
- **Hydrocarbons** - Alkanes, alkenes, alkynes
- **Functional Groups** - Alcohols, carboxylic acids, and more
- **IUPAC Nomenclature** - Systematic naming
- **Biomolecules** - Proteins, carbohydrates, polymers

> ðŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** Carbon can form over 10 million different compounds - more than all other elements combined!

## Why Carbon is Special

| Property | Significance |
|----------|-------------|
| 4 valence electrons | Can form 4 bonds |
| Catenation | Forms long chains and rings |
| Multiple bonding | Single, double, triple |
| Bond stability | Strong C-C and C-H bonds |

## Organic vs Inorganic

| Organic | Inorganic |
|---------|----------|
| Contains carbon | Usually no carbon |
| Covalent bonding | Often ionic |
| Low melting points | High melting points |
| Life-based | Mineral-based |

## Applications

- ðŸ’Š Pharmaceuticals
- ðŸ§´ Plastics and polymers
- â›½ Fuels
- ðŸŽ Food and nutrition
- ðŸ§¬ Biochemistry

Let's explore the world of carbon!

slides.title: IUPAC Nomenclature
slides.content:
# IUPAC Nomenclature ðŸ“

## Naming Steps

### 1. Find longest carbon chain (parent)

| Carbons | Prefix |
|---------|--------|
| 1 | Meth- |
| 2 | Eth- |
| 3 | Prop- |
| 4 | But- |
| 5 | Pent- |
| 6 | Hex- |

### 2. Identify functional groups (suffix)

| Group | Suffix |
|-------|--------|
| Alkane | -ane |
| Alkene | -ene |
| Alkyne | -yne |
| Alcohol | -ol |
| Aldehyde | -al |
| Ketone | -one |
| Carboxylic acid | -oic acid |

### 3. Number the chain
- Start from end closest to highest priority group

### 4. Name substituents

| Substituent | Prefix |
|-------------|--------|
| â”€CHâ‚ƒ | methyl- |
| â”€Cl | chloro- |
| â”€Br | bromo- |
| â”€OH | hydroxy- |

### 5. Assemble the name
Substituents (alphabetically) + position + parent + suffix

## Examples

```
    CHâ‚ƒâ”€CHâ‚‚â”€CHâ‚‚â”€CHâ‚ƒ â†’ Butane
    
    CHâ‚ƒâ”€CH(CHâ‚ƒ)â”€CHâ‚ƒ â†’ 2-Methylpropane
    
    CHâ‚‚=CHâ”€CHâ‚ƒ â†’ Propene
    
    CHâ‚ƒâ”€CHâ‚‚â”€OH â†’ Ethanol
    
    CHâ‚ƒâ”€CH(OH)â”€CHâ‚ƒ â†’ Propan-2-ol
```

> ðŸ’¡ **Tip:** Practice naming structures both ways: name â†’ structure and structure â†’ name!

slides.title: Isomerism
slides.content:
# Isomerism ðŸ”„

Isomers have the **same molecular formula** but **different structures**.

## Types of Isomerism

### 1. Structural (Constitutional) Isomerism

**Chain Isomerism**
```
Câ‚„Hâ‚â‚€:  CHâ‚ƒ-CHâ‚‚-CHâ‚‚-CHâ‚ƒ  (butane)
        CHâ‚ƒ-CH(CHâ‚ƒ)-CHâ‚ƒ   (2-methylpropane)
```

**Position Isomerism**
```
Câ‚ƒHâ‚ˆO:  CHâ‚ƒ-CHâ‚‚-CHâ‚‚-OH  (propan-1-ol)
        CHâ‚ƒ-CH(OH)-CHâ‚ƒ   (propan-2-ol)
```

**Functional Group Isomerism**
```
Câ‚‚Hâ‚†O:  CHâ‚ƒ-CHâ‚‚-OH  (ethanol - alcohol)
        CHâ‚ƒ-O-CHâ‚ƒ   (dimethyl ether)
```

### 2. Stereoisomerism

**Geometric (cis-trans) Isomerism**
```
        H     H              H     CHâ‚ƒ
         \   /                \   /
          C=C                  C=C
         /   \                /   \
       CHâ‚ƒ   CHâ‚ƒ            CHâ‚ƒ    H
        cis                  trans
```

**Optical Isomerism**
- Four different groups on one carbon
- Mirror images (enantiomers)
- Rotate polarized light

## Why Isomers Matter

| Property | Can differ between isomers |
|----------|---------------------------|
| Boiling point | Yes |
| Solubility | Yes |
| Biological activity | Yes! |
| Reactivity | Yes |

> ðŸŽ¯ **Important:** Many drugs have isomers where only one form is active or safe!

# Polymers ðŸ§¬

## What are Polymers?

```
Monomer + Monomer + Monomer + ... â†’ Polymer
(small units)                     (long chain)
```

## Types of Polymerization

### Addition Polymerization

```
nCHâ‚‚=CHâ‚‚ â†’ [â”€CHâ‚‚â”€CHâ‚‚â”€]â‚™

```

### Condensation Polymerization

Monomers join with loss of small molecule (water):

```
Diacid + Diamine â†’ Polyamide + Hâ‚‚O
                   (Nylon)
```

## Common Addition Polymers

| Monomer | Polymer | Use |
|---------|---------|-----|
| Ethene | Polyethylene (PE) | Bags, bottles |
| Propene | Polypropylene (PP) | Containers |
| Styrene | Polystyrene (PS) | Packaging |
| Vinyl chloride | PVC | Pipes |
| Tetrafluoroethene | PTFE (Teflon) | Non-stick |

## Common Condensation Polymers

| Type | Linkage | Example |
|------|---------|--------|
| Polyester | â”€COOâ”€ | PET (bottles) |
| Polyamide | â”€CONHâ”€ | Nylon |

## Polymer Properties

| Property | Depends on |
|----------|------------|
| Strength | Chain length, crosslinking |
| Flexibility | Chain structure |
| Melting point | Intermolecular forces |
| Crystallinity | Chain regularity |

## Environmental Concerns

- Most synthetic polymers are non-biodegradable
- Accumulate in environment
- Solutions: Recycling, biodegradable polymers

> ðŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** Proteins and DNA are natural polymers!
